docs.title: Gradient of a scalar field
docs.text:
The gradient of a scalar function is defined as \(\nabla f\) or \(\vec{grad} f\)

it is given by:

docs.title: steps
docs.text:
Find the divergence of the following vetor field: \(\vec{f}(x, y) = x^2 y^2 \vec{i} - x^3 y^2 \vec{j}\)

  1. Identify the components of \(\vec{f}(x, y)\)
  2. \(F_x = x^2 + y^3\)
  3. \(F_y = x^3 + y^2\)
  4. Apply the formula
  5. \(\vec{\nabla} . \vec{F} = \frac{∂F_x}{∂x} + \frac{∂F_y}{y∂}\)
  6. substitute the values of \(F_x\) and \(F_y\)
  7. solve: \(= 2x y^3 - 2y x^3\)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Find the divergence of the following vetor field:

i) \(\vec{f}(x, y) = x^2 y^2 \vec{i} - x^3 y^2 \vec{j}\) \(= 2x y^3 - 2y x^3\) ii) \(\vec{f}(x, y, z) = (xy - xz) \vec{i} + 3 x^2 \vec{j} + yz \vec{k}\) \(\vec{div} f = 2y - z\)

docs.title: Curl of a vector field
docs.text:
The curl is denoted by \(\vec{ abla} \cross \vec{F}\) or \(curl \vec{F}\)

We still apply the same formula for nabla as we used before, except we apply it in 3 dimensions and find the cross product with the vector components.

\(\vec{ abla} x \vec{F} = ?\)

\(\vec{F} = F_x \vec{i} + F_y \vec{j} + F_z \vec{k}\) \(\vec{ abla} = rac{∂}{∂x} \vec{i} + rac{∂}{∂y} \vec{j} + rac{∂}{∂z} \vec{k}\)

Then find the cross product of those both using matrix method.

  2. Apply the formula to get \(\vec{\nabla}\).

docs.title: Chapter 2: Differentiation
docs.text:
Differentiation is the process of finding the derivative of a function. derivative of a function \(f(x)\) is \(f'(x)\) or \(dy/dx\).

  • Polynomial functions:
  • Constant rule: \(\frac{dC}{dx} = 0\).
  • Power rule: \(\frac{d(x^n)}{dx} = nx^{n-1}\)
  • Constant multiple: \(\frac{d(a*g(x))}{dx} = a*g'(x)\)
  • Sum/Difference: \(\frac{d(a + b + c + ...)}{dx} = a' + b' + c' + ...\)
  • Irrational functions:
  • If \(\frac{d(\sqrt{g(x)})}{dx} = \frac{g'(x)}{2√(g(x))}\)
  • Exponential: \(\frac{d(e^u)}{dx} = u'*e^u\)
  • Logarithmic:
  • Trigonometric: ...

  • Power: \((u^r)'\) = ru'u^{r-1}$

  • Chain rule: If \(y = f(u)\) and \(u = f(x)\), then \(\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{dy}{du} * \frac{dy}{dx}\)

docs.title: I -  Generalities
docs.text:
We know that \(y = f(x)\) is used to represent a function of one variable. In this case the input is \(x\) and the output is \(f(x)\).

\(x\) can be called independent or input variable, while \(y\) is the dependent derived or output variable, for functions of several variables.

Functions of several variables are those taking more than one input value. e.g \(f(x, y)\) or \(f(x, y, z)\).

Total derivative is the derivative of a funciin dependng on only one variable while partial derivative depends on more.

The partial derivative of a function is the derivative with respect to one of the variables while keeping the others constant.

Partial derivative of \(f(x, y, z)\) with respect to \(x\) is denoted by \(\frac{∂f}{∂x}\) or \(f_x\).

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Find the partial derivative of the following functions with respect to \(x\) and \(y\):

  1. \(f(x, y) = x^3 + x + y^2 + y\)
  2. \(f(x, y) = yx^2 + xy^3\)
  3. \(f(x, y) = x^3 + 2yx^2 + y^2 + 2x - 1\)
  4. \(f(x, y) = 2x^2 y^2 + xe^{xy}\) for \(f_x(-1, 2)\) and \(f_y(-3, -0)\)

docs.title: Second order partial derivatives
docs.text: The second order partial derivative of \(f\) with respect to \(x\) is denoted as \(\frac{∂^2 f}{∂x^2}\) or \(f_{xx}\).

docs.title: Mixed derivatives
docs.text:
They are denoted \(f_{xy}\), which means partial derivative with respect to \(y\), then partial with respect to \(x\).

When a function satisfies \(f_{xy} = f_{yx}\) it is said to satisfy [Schwarz's theorem].

docs.title: Example 2
docs.text:
Find the following partial derivatives: \(f_{xx}\), \(f_{yy}\), $f_{xy} and \(f_{yx}\) for the following functions.

  1. \(f(x, y) = x^3 + x^2 y^2 + 2y^3 + 2x + y\)
  2. \(f_{xx}(-1, 1); f_{yy}(-2, 2)\) for \(f(x, y) = xe^{xy} + x^2 ye^y + 2x^3 y^2\)

docs.title: Professionalism
docs.text:
Conduct or ways which marks a professinal accross his field or domain.

Professionalism is perceived via a set of attributes which make of one profession, proffesionalism and a person which executes such attributes is a professional, and include:

  • Expertise or specialized knowledge: A professional has expertise in his domain, and knows what he or she is doing. A professional has acquired skills, degrees and certificates. e.g a PHD in law means one has specialized knowledge in law.
  • Competency: The get the job done and don't make excuses and focus solely on finding solutions, this is actually tight to their Expertise.
  • Honesty and Integrity: ...
  • Accountability: A professional should be able to open up and be accountable if he makes mistakes while doing his job, he should be fully responsible of his mistakes.
  • Regulation: He should be emotionaly intelligent and regulate properly his interactions with others:
  • Comming early.
  • Be polite.
  • Punctuality.
  • Self-discipline.
  • Up to date: A professional keeps himself up to date.
  • Active listening and communication: He should be able to convey his message, using the right words, not listening to everything but what is important.
  • Have the right tools: He should have the right tools to use and inform himself.
  • Time management: A profesional should have defined time frames for his activities.

docs.title: Good governance
docs.text:
Governance is the decision and implementation.

Decisions are made in consideration of every affected person(what citizens wish and need, ...) and implemented fairly.

Good governance is the transparent, accountable and efficient management of a government, organization or other institution's resources and members.

docs.title: Principles of good governance
docs.text:
• Parcitipation: Everyone should participate, directly or inderectly.
  • Direct participation:
    • A minister or president directly governs.
  • Indirect
    • A teacher indirectly help students
  • Transparency: The institution's governance should be completely transparent and well-known by citizens.

  • Responsiveness: It should try to meet up to all stakeholders needs (farmers, citizens, ...).

  • Accountability: The institution should be accountable to it's citizens of it's actions and how it uses resources.

  • Participation: Citizens should participate in decision-making.
  • Rules of law: The law should apply to every citizen or administration member, no one is above the law .
  • Human rights: Humans rights are part of the law and should always be respected.
  • Good decision making and implementation: They should make good decisions and implement those decisions fairly.

The median class is the middle class in the distribution. If the number of classes is even, it is the the one of the middle classes with the higher frequency.

docs.title: Inflation
docs.text: Inflation is the persistent increase in the general price of goods and services in an economy leading the the constant drop of the currency's value.

docs.title: Causes of inflation
docs.text:
• Increase in demand.
  • Increase in population.
  • Increase in money supply. When the increase in supply of money outweights the output of good and services, it couses inflation.

docs.title: Cost pull inflation
docs.text: When the general price of goods and services increases due to the increase in cose of factors of production(or simply increase in cost of production)

docs.title: Effects of inflation

docs.title: The PPC(Production Possibility Curve)
docs.text: Opportunity cost is the next best opportunity forgone. The PPC is a line/curve which shows the different possible combinations of two products which can be prduced by a single firm/nation using all of it's available resources at a static technology and point in time.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Given a bakery, where we have: - Resources: - 1 Oven - 1 Worker - Products: - Bread - Cakes

The data is given as follows:

Breads Cakes 216 0 180 48 144 96 108 144 72 192 36 240 0 288 
using Plots
plt = plot(0:48:288, 216:-36:0; xlabel="Cakes", ylabel="Bread", label="PPC")

docs.title: Points on the PPC
docs.text:
• Points on the PPC: All points on the PPC are efficient, the PPC line or curve represens the best and maximum ammount of product which can be made all resources used to their full.
  • Points in the curve: The represent inefficient production due to idle resources, we can still improve on the production of both goods using available resources.
  • Points outside the PPC: The PPC represents already the maximum, which is the limit of production, going above this line is impossible to acheive since our resources used to the fullest make us arrive to the PPC. Factors pushing PPC outwards include:
  • Discovery of new resources.

docs.title: Shifts on the PPC
docs.text: These are factors which may make the PPC buldge inwards or outwards - Outwards: - Innovation, or improve in technology. - Improvement in quality of education. - Increase in population. - Discovery of idle resources: - Population(human labour). - Inwards: - Inflation - National disasters

docs.title: Levels of efficiency on the curve
docs.text:
• Productive: Basically an increast in output.
  • Allocative: When the resources allocated basically for the production of a particular good.
  • Pareto: The normal scenario, at this point of efficiency No good can be made better off without another good be made worse of.

docs.title: Karnaugh Map(K-Map)
docs.text: A k-map is a graphical method used to simplify boolean expressions. It provides a systematic way of minimising boolean functions without lengthy boolean algebra, they are widely used in digital electronics to design efficient logic circuits. K-maps loog gray code ordering where only one variabe changes between adjecent cells. This makes it easy to identify common variables and eliminate redundant variables.

docs.title: How to obtain a boolean expression solution from K-map
docs.text:
• Identify the variables in the boolean function or thruth table and represent them in the k-map.
  • Fill the k-map with 1's corresponding to the given min terms.
  • Group adjescent 1's with powers of 2.
  • For each group, identify variables which remain constant and eliminate changing variables.
  • Write the boolean term for each group.
  • Combine all terms using OR to get the final simplified expression.

docs.title: The waterfall model
docs.text:
This contains an organist steps each leading to the other.

  • Requirement gathering
  • System analysis
  • Coding
  • Testing
  • Integrate(Implement)
  • Maintenance

It is that schema, where every step pours into the other that we call waterfall model.

docs.title: Advantages
docs.text:
• Clear structure: When you finish a step, you get to the other.
  • Error detection: Easily detect possible errors
  • Easy to manage:
  • More accurate goals: Allows you to determine the overall project goals.
  • Reduce dev issues: Reduces development issues.

docs.title: Advantages
docs.text:
• Rigid: It is rigid, or one-way only. If the requirements change while we are in the coding phase, there is no way back.
  • Excludes clients and users: Clients and users are not mentioned and are not part of the model.
  • Not suitable for complex projects

docs.title: The V-Shape model
docs.text:
The V-Shape model is an extension of the waterfall model. It has stems devised into two, and causing it's V-Shape

  • Verification: The practice and evaluating of development period, includes:
  • Business req analysis: Understand product requirements
  • System analysis System eng analyze and interpret business requirements.
  • Sw arch design Selecting sw structures based on identified modules, functions and relevant technical elements. Some strategies guiding how modules are tested together are planed.
  • Module design Divide the software into small modules
  • Coding: Dev team selects a suitable programming language based on requirements. Multiple reviews for coding standard.
  • Validation: Dynamic analysis, methods and testing to be sure the product meet the user requirements
  • Unit testing Identify and find errors at the unit level in small individual isolated parts of the software.
  • Integration Testing Executing integration tests dev in architecture, to make sure unit parts can coexist and work together after being tested to work individually.
  • System testing Executing system tests and testing the whole system with tests from system development tests. Ensures that the team meets the expectations
  • Acceptation testing Identify non-functional issues like growth and performance.

docs.title: Advantages
docs.text:
• Early error detection, testing done at each stage
  • Improve quality with frequent tests
  • Easy to manage and well-defined steps
  • Good for large or complex projects(not like [Waterfall])

docs.title: Disadvantages
docs.text:
• It is inflexible, making changes are difficult
  • Hard cost
  • Late delivery
  • Not suitable for complex projects
  • Assume requirements are ...

Why the V shape? The V-Shape is very simple, every left step on the model which is an implementation has a corresponding horizontally parallel testing step.

docs.title: Scrum
docs.text:
It is a method originating from Japan.

The scrum focuses on 3 parts:

A spring is like a process devised into steps, while increments are output after each springs.

  • Iterative process
  • Work increments each cycle is to give a better output

  • Collaboration: Enforce collaboration and team work.

  • Product backlog: An organized list with requirement needed to run the project.

  • Spring backlog: Items from the previous for the current spring.

docs.title: Key principles
docs.text:
• Adaptability to change: In each of the steps, the project can easily be modified.
  • Transparency: It is made up of visible steps permitting to review progress and list of items in backlog.

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text: • Fast product delivery: At each stage a product is made which is improved for the next step.

docs.title: Advantages
docs.text:
• Requires expensive expertise.
  • No hard deadlines
  • Difficult to estimate the resources

docs.title: Advantages
docs.text:
• Is more interactive.
  • Adaptability and flexibility.
  • Improves the team morale, since members are working together with frequent spring meetings.
  • Reduces wastage of resources.

docs.title: Linear independence
docs.text:
A set of vectors, \(\{V_1, V_2, V_3, ..., V_n\}\) is said to be linearly independent in a vector space \(\mathbb{V}\) is said to be linearly independent if the only solution to the vector equation

\(C_1*V_1 + C_2 * V_2 + ... = 0\) where \(C_1 = C_2 = C_3 = ... = C_n = 0\)

  • \(C_1 = C_2 = C_3 = ... = C_n\) The above equation is a trivial solution. -> if there exists any non-trivial solution(Where at lrease one of the C_n is non-zero), the set of vectors is Linearly dependent.

  • If \(A\) is an \(n x n\) sqare matrix or that the vector space, you can use their determinant as a quick test id est: \(if \\det A ≠ 0\) the vectors are linearly independent If \(\\det A = 0\) then the vectors are linearly dependent. example: If the three vectors julia A = [a_1, a_2, a_3] B = [b_1, b_2, b_3] C = [c_1, c_2, c_3] The three vectors are linearly independent if the determinant of the matrix: [A B C] is not equal to 0.

docs.title: Linear transformations
docs.text:
Linear transformations are functions mapping vectors while preserving the properties of vector addition and scalar multiplication.

Let \(V\) and \(W\) be two vector spaces over the same field \(F\). A mapping \(T: V \rightarrow W\) is called a linear transformation.

  1. \(T(u+v) = T(u) + T(v); ∀ u,v ∈ \mathbb{C}\)
  2. \(T(αu) = αT(u); ∀ α ∈ \mathbb{R}\)

docs.title: Intro-like
docs.text: Microsoft powerpoint is considered as a publishing tool, you can use it to create presentations``, organised throughslides. And optionally but very advice, to addtransitions` between them.

docs.title: The first view
docs.text:
The first view, that which you get when you are just from opening your your powerpoint and creating a new blank presentation is a blank page containing two text boxes:

  • The first and higher text box for the big title.
  • The second and lower text box for a subtitle.

docs.title: Font sizes, fonts and spacing
docs.text: For text layout, it is instead recommended a font size of minimum 20px(I personally prefer 23px), and a line spacing of 1.5.

docs.title: Bullet points
docs.text:
When dealing with bullet points, use not more than 3-4 points per slide, and 3 lines per point for better readability.

[!TIP] You can put transitions on the bullets to let them show one at a time and individually capture better your audience attention.

docs.title: Slides numbers
docs.text:
[!WARNING] NUMBER YOUR SLIDES

I advice you strongly to make use of page numbers, as for dealing with MS Word they are in the View tab(or maybe something else).

[!WARNING] Don't forget to check the Don't show on title slide checkbox.

docs.title: Transitions
docs.text:
Transitions are a very useful tool on powerpoint, they have a dedicated menu tab, and help your presentations look more attractive by adding animations between your slides.

I really advice you to use them.

[!TIP] You can enable automatic slideshow in the transitions tab(On the end right side) to let the slides switch on their own.
